population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 44-65 with a BMI of 27-39 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 30 g of soy protein and 4 g of phytosterols per day.

study_goal: To determine if a chronic low-glycemic index (LGI) diet improves plasma glucose control, lipid metabolism, fat mass, and insulin resistance in type 2 diabetic patients compared to a high-glycemic index (HGI) diet.
results_summary: The LGI diet improved postprandial glucose and insulin profiles, fasting plasma glucose, HbA1c, whole-body glucose utilization, and certain lipid profiles compared to the HGI diet. No significant changes in body weight or total fat mass were observed.
population_specificity: Twelve type 2 diabetic men.
study_duration: Two 4-week dietary periods separated by a 4-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if parents of overweight children could effectively lower the glycemic index (GI) of their child's diet after brief instructions and assess the diet's impact on BMI.
results_summary: The study found that 14 of 15 children lowered their GI score significantly, with reduced carbohydrate and caloric intake. BMI Z-scores decreased in 12 of 15 children, suggesting feasibility of the LGI diet in primary care.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-12 years with BMIs greater than the 95th percentile.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term effects of a low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet with either low glycemic index (LGI) or high glycemic index (HGI) on energy intake, body weight, composition, and risk factors for type 2 diabetes and ischemic heart disease in overweight healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between LGI and HGI diets in energy intake, body weight, or fat mass reduction. However, the LGI diet showed a 10% decrease in LDL cholesterol and a tendency toward greater total cholesterol reduction compared to the HGI diet.
population_specificity: 45 healthy overweight women aged 20-40 years (BMI: 27.6 ± 0.2).
effective_dosage: Not specified (test foods replaced usual carbohydrate-rich foods, matched for energy, density, fiber, and macronutrients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of a low glycemic index diet on glycemic risk factors (A1C and PPG) in people with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) or T2DM with dyslipidemia.
results_summary: The study found that a low glycemic index diet (average glycemic index 59) reduced A1C levels, though results were controversial due to confounding variables and underpowered studies. Psyllium supplementation also improved glycemic risk factors, but the role of the low glycemic index diet requires further well-designed trials.
population_specificity: People with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) or T2DM and dyslipidemia.
effective_dosage: Average glycemic index of 59 (specific dietary details not provided).

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of varying the glycemic index (GI) of carbohydrate-rich foods on metabolic control in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: The low-GI diet significantly improved peripheral insulin sensitivity, reduced fasting plasma glucose, lowered LDL cholesterol more than the high-GI diet, and normalized plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 activity. The incremental glucose and insulin responses were approximately 30% lower on the low-GI diet.
population_specificity: 20 type 2 diabetic patients (5 women, 15 men).
effective_dosage: Preweighed diets with different GIs (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-glycemic index (GI) diet versus a standard reduced-fat diet on BMI and body weight in obese children.
results_summary: The low-GI diet group showed significantly greater reductions in BMI (-1.53 kg/m²) and body weight (-2.03 kg) compared to the reduced-fat diet group. More patients in the low-GI group achieved a BMI reduction of at least 3 kg/m² (17.2% vs. 2.3%).
population_specificity: 107 obese but otherwise healthy children attending an outpatient pediatric obesity program.
study_duration: Mean follow-up of 4.3 months for the low-GI group and 4.2 months for the reduced-fat group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of various physical processing techniques on legume starch properties and their implications for developing low-glycemic index (GI) foods.
results_summary: Certain physical processing methods (e.g., heat-moisture treatment, ultrahigh-pressure processing) enhanced resistant or slowly digestible starch fractions, beneficial for low-GI foods, while others (e.g., annealing, extrusion) increased starch digestibility, which is less favorable for such applications. The review provides a comparative analysis of these methods and their effects on legume starch digestibility.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of processing techniques, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low- and high-glycemic-index foods on 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure in women.
results_summary: The study found significant decreases in systolic and diastolic blood pressure during the low-glycemic-index period, but no significant changes during the high-glycemic-index period.
population_specificity: 30 women aged 18 to 40 years.
study_duration: 24 hours per intervention period, with a 2-week washout between periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand which Theory of Planned Behaviour constructs, demographic characteristics, and diabetes-related variables best predict intention to consume a low-glycemic-index diet among people with diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that instrumental attitude, subjective norms, and perceived behavioral control significantly predicted intentions to eat a low-GI diet. Older age, higher income, female gender, type 2 diabetes, diet-only treatment, and understanding of the GI were positively associated with intention to consume a low-GI diet.
population_specificity: 369 adults (30-75 years) with type 1 or type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of low-glycemic-index (GI) foods on metabolic disturbances in diabetic, hyperlipidemic, and metabolic syndrome patients.
results_summary: The study found that low-GI foods significantly improve postprandial blood glucose, insulin variations, plasma lipid levels, and adipocyte morphology and function. It also suggests that low-GI foods can be combined with other therapies for better diabetes control.
population_specificity: Diabetic, hyperlipidemic, and metabolic syndrome patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding a low-glycemic-index (GI) food component to a walking program improved health outcomes in people with type 2 diabetes compared to a walking-only program.
results_summary: The study found that while both groups increased physical activity and reduced waist and hip girth, adding low-GI foods did not significantly improve anthropometric or metabolic outcomes compared to the walking-only program. The authors suggested that a greater quantity or longer duration of low-GI foods might be needed for clinical improvements.
population_specificity: People with type 2 diabetes in good glycemic control (n=22 per group, n=19 at follow-up).
effective_dosage: Not specified (monitored daily intake of low-GI foods).
study_duration: 16 weeks (4 weekly group meetings, minimal follow-up weeks 5-16).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of a 6-week low Glycemic Load (GL) diet based on low Glycemic Index (GI) foods on body weight, body composition, metabolic risk factors, and satiety in overweight/obese pre-pubertal children.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in body fat percentage, waist-to-hip ratio, self-reported hunger levels, and total cardiovascular risk factors, despite no change in body weight. A strong negative correlation was observed between fasting glucose and insulin levels.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese pre-pubertal children (average age 11, BMI 24.7 +/- 3.8 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Replacement of at least 50% of high GI foods with low-GI foods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high- and low-glycemic index (GI) diets on glycemic control and plasma lipids in patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM).
results_summary: The low-GI diet modestly improved long-term glycemic control (11% lower glycosylated hemoglobin and reduced plasma glucose profile) compared to the high-GI diet, but no significant differences were observed in plasma lipids.
population_specificity: Sixteen subjects with well-controlled NIDDM and normal lipid profile, 10 of whom continued oral hypoglycemic medication.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diets were matched for macronutrient composition and fiber).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the in vitro activity of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on inhibiting the growth of Malassezia pachydermatis.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant decline in colony-forming units (CFUs) of M. pachydermatis after a minimum of 4 minutes of LLLT exposure compared to unexposed controls, demonstrating its potential to inhibit fungal growth.
population_specificity: Clinical isolates of M. pachydermatis (n = 30) and a commercially available anamorph of M. pachydermatis (ATCC strain 14522).
effective_dosage: 2, 4, 6, and 8 minutes of exposure with 30-second breaks after every 2 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of preoperative low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on postoperative pain, swelling, and trismus following mandibular third molar extractions.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between the LLLT and control groups in pain, swelling, or trismus at 24 hours, 48 hours, or 7 days postoperatively. However, LLLT showed clinically acceptable effects, suggesting potential benefits despite the lack of statistical significance.
population_specificity: 28 patients (23 female, 5 male) aged 18-45 years with bilaterally impacted mandibular third molars in similar positions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined effect of Sodium Alendronate in Carbapol gel and Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on peri-implant tissue healing in Wistar rat femurs.
results_summary: Groups treated with LLLT (Groups 3 and 4) showed bony union and reorganized spongiosa, while control groups (1 and 2) exhibited fibrous union. The combination of Sodium Alendronate and LLLT (Group 3) resulted in adult-type fatty marrow, indicating enhanced healing.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with mini implants in femur bones.
effective_dosage: LLLT (CO2 laser, 830nm wavelength, 2.1J/cm²) applied on days 1, 7, 14, and 21; Sodium Alendronate (1mg in Carbapol gel) applied once at implant placement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal irradiation conditions (beam application method, power, and dose) of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for enhancing macrophage viability and secretory activity in RAW 264.7 cells.
results_summary: The study found that a pulsed laser beam at 200 mW power and a dose of 5 J/cm² increased macrophage adhesion, viability, and NO secretion while reducing TNF-α, MCP-1, and MMP-9 secretion. The effects of LLLT on macrophages depended on irradiation parameters like wavelength, power, dose, and beam application method.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophage cell line (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and analyze existing systematic reviews and meta-analyses on Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) to determine its effects and optimal parameters for treating diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
results_summary: The study found that photobiomodulation (PBM) with various parameters was effective in promoting DFU healing compared to standard treatment and non-irradiation treatments, though no statistically significant difference was observed between different wavelengths (632 nm and 904 nm). Further research is needed to identify ideal parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
effective_dosage: Red and infrared wavelengths were used, with specific parameters not detailed in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the temperature changes in laryngeal tissues of swine before and after single or multiple doses of red and infrared low-level laser therapy (LLLT).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT caused temperature variations in the larynx, with single doses of red laser increasing temperature in young animals and multiple doses of infrared laser increasing temperature in adult animals. Combined laser therapy also showed significant temperature differences before and after application.
population_specificity: Swine (young and adult animals)
effective_dosage: Single and multiple doses of red (RL) and infrared (IRL) lasers
study_duration: Acute response measured after 1 and 8 doses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in managing maxillofacial neuropathies, focusing on pain reduction, neurological recovery, and tissue regeneration.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain scores, facilitated faster sensory recovery, and improved tissue regeneration markers, with mild adverse events reported in <5% of cases. The study concluded that LLLT is effective and safe for managing maxillofacial neuropathies.
population_specificity: Patients with paresthesia, neuralgia, or facial paralysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity laser therapy (HILT) and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on disability and quadriceps architecture in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: LLLT improved functional ability (WOMAC scores) and increased VMO thickness in knee osteoarthritis patients, though HILT showed greater functional improvement after one month. No significant changes were observed in VL structures or VMO fiber angle and volume.
population_specificity: 98 patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA) selected by convenience sampling.
study_duration: Evaluations were performed before, immediately after, and one month post-intervention (exact duration of intervention not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the applications and effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in dentistry, focusing on its anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and biostimulatory effects.
results_summary: LLLT was found to reduce pain and swelling, accelerate wound healing, promote tissue regeneration, and manage conditions like temporomandibular disorders (TMDs) and oral mucositis. It also aided in orthodontics by speeding up tooth movement and reducing associated pain.
population_specificity: Dental patients (broad applications, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dual-wavelength combinations of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) enhance hair regrowth in mice compared to single-wavelength treatment.
results_summary: The study found that dual-wavelength LLLT was superior to single-wavelength treatment and significantly more effective than the untreated control, demonstrating improved hair regrowth. Results were analyzed through surface image analysis and histological examination.
population_specificity: Mice (shaved for hair regrowth assessment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the effects of photobiomodulation (PBM) at the intestinal level on intestinal dysbiosis and neuroinflammation.
results_summary: The study found that PBM modulates the gut microbiota and may serve as a therapy for neurological conditions affecting the gut-brain axis, though further research is needed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) accelerates orthodontic tooth movement and reduces patient discomfort during treatment.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly increased the rate of tooth movement (1.2 mm/month vs. 0.8 mm/month in controls) and reduced early-phase discomfort, with no significant differences in gingival health between groups.
population_specificity: 60 orthodontic patients aged 15-25 (30 males, 30 females).
effective_dosage: 808 nm diode laser, 100 mW power, 30 s per side of target tooth, 3 times/week for 8 weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks (8 weeks of active intervention, 4 weeks of follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Photobiomodulation (Low-Level Laser Therapy) in treating chemoradiotherapy-induced mucositis in cancer patients.
results_summary: The laser group showed significant reductions in pain scores and mucositis severity within the first week, along with improved quality of life, though no significant difference was observed at one month compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 36 patients with grade 3-4 oral mucositis induced by chemoradiotherapy for head and neck cancer.
effective_dosage: 810 nm wavelength, 200 mW power, 6 J/cm² energy density for 4 days.
study_duration: 4 days of intervention, with follow-ups at one week and one month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effects of LLLT with ESWT and PEMF on pain, function, and quality of life in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved pain, physical function, and quality of life in knee OA patients, with results comparable to ESWT and superior to PEMF. No significant differences were found between LLLT and ESWT.
population_specificity: 120 patients with Kellgren-Lawrence grade 2-3 knee osteoarthritis, randomized into four groups (30 per group).
effective_dosage: Twice a week for eight sessions.
study_duration: Eight sessions over an unspecified number of weeks (frequency: twice weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of aquatic progressive resistance exercise (APRE) and photobiomodulation (PBM) on skeletal muscle morphology and biochemical markers in a rat model of knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that APRE reduced muscle atrophy markers, and its combination with PBM modulated molecules involved in muscle recovery. Both trained groups showed reduced atrogin expression and increased myoD immunoexpression.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Laser irradiation (808 nm) applied to 2 points of the knee joint, 3 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of adding low-level laser therapy (LLLT) or neuromuscular electrical nerve stimulation (NMES) to conventional physical therapy exercises for treating hemiplegic shoulder pain (HSP) in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT, NMES, and conventional therapy all significantly improved upper extremity function and disability in stroke patients with HSP, with LLLT and NMES showing greater improvements in pain and disability compared to conventional therapy alone. The effects of LLLT and NMES were statistically similar.
population_specificity: Seventy-five stroke patients with hemiplegic shoulder pain.
effective_dosage: LLLT was administered three days a week for four weeks (total of twelve sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of minoxidil alone versus minoxidil combined with Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for treating androgenic alopecia.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no statistically significant differences in hair counts or hair diameter between minoxidil alone and minoxidil combined with LLLT at baseline, 12 weeks, and 8 weeks post-treatment. The combination therapy did not improve outcomes compared to minoxidil monotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with androgenic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining stem cell-laden tubular constructs with Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) improved sciatic nerve repair in rats compared to autografts or stem cell constructs alone.
results_summary: The study found that stem cell constructs combined with LLLT showed efficacy in sciatic nerve repair, with improved distal latency compared to stem cell-only treatment, though autografts still performed best in functional recovery (SFI). No significant differences in axonal count or nerve repair scores were observed among groups.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (250-300 g) with surgically excised sciatic nerves.
effective_dosage: Not specified (LLLT parameters not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) alone versus LLLT combined with pharmacotherapy (Aceclofenac) in treating myofascial pain associated with temporomandibular disorders.
results_summary: Both LLLT alone and LLLT combined with Aceclofenac significantly reduced pain and improved mouth opening, with the combination therapy showing faster results. The study concluded that both treatments are effective, but the combination was more efficient.
population_specificity: Forty patients with myofascial pain dysfunction syndrome (MPDS), with or without other temporomandibular disorders.
effective_dosage: LLLT (BiolaseTM; GA-Al-As; 940 nm) in 12 sessions; Aceclofenac 200 mg until the end of the 12th session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on spasticity in children with cerebral palsy and identify gaps for future research.
results_summary: The review found that LLLT reduced spasticity in children with cerebral palsy, with some studies also reporting reduced pain and increased muscle strength. However, methodological inconsistencies and lack of standardized parameters limit the strength of these findings.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (SCP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in improving postoperative recovery outcomes (bite force, pain, mouth opening, and paresthesia) in patients with zygomatic bone fractures.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant improvements in trismus (days 7 and 14), pain reduction (days 1, 2, 7, and 14), and paresthesia (days 7 and 14) compared to placebo, but no significant effect on bite force.
population_specificity: Patients with fractures of the zygomatic bone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Laser Therapy (HILT) and Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain, disability, range of motion, pain pressure threshold, and sleep quality in patients with Subacromial Impingement Syndrome (SAIS).
results_summary: Both HILT and LLLT groups showed significant improvements in pain, disability, range of motion, pain pressure threshold, and sleep quality compared to the control group, with HILT demonstrating larger effect sizes in most outcomes.
population_specificity: 42 patients with Subacromial Impingement Syndrome (SAIS).
effective_dosage: LLLT at 904 nm, three times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of combining fractional Er:YAG laser with either PRP or LLLT versus using fractional Er:YAG laser alone for improving postsurgical and post-traumatic scars.
results_summary: Group B (Er:YAG + LLLT) showed significant improvements in vascularity and total VSS score compared to Group C (Er:YAG alone), though Group A (Er:YAG + PRP) had the best outcomes. Patient satisfaction was higher in combined therapy groups than in the laser-only group.
population_specificity: 45 individuals with post-surgical or post-traumatic scars.
study_duration: Four fractional Er:YAG laser sessions spaced four weeks apart, with LLLT administered weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of short-term and long-term low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on mandibular alveolar bone in osteoporotic rats.
results_summary: Short-term LLLT showed partial improvement in alveolar bone with slight changes in RANKL and OPG levels, while long-term LLLT demonstrated significant positive changes in bone quality, quantity, and organization, with marked regulation of RANKL and OPG levels.
population_specificity: Adult male albino rats with induced osteoporosis.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (short-term vs. long-term application, but exact durations not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for immediate pain relief in patients with Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS).
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain immediately after treatment, with 71.3% of patients reporting pain reduction and a mean VAS decrease of 2.2 (39.9% reduction). Factors like low baseline VAS, smoking/alcohol history, xerostomia, and gingival lesions correlated with worse efficacy. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 94 patients with Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) compared to formocresol as a pulpotomy agent in primary molars.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference between LLLT and formocresol in clinical and radiographic success at 6-9 and 12-month follow-ups, suggesting LLLT is a viable alternative for reversible pulpitis.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-10 years with primary molars requiring pulpotomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the effects of diode laser irradiation on the proliferation and cytotoxicity of mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) and human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs).
results_summary: The study found that 810 nm diode laser irradiation increased cell proliferation in both MEFs and HGFs, with 100% proliferation observed in MEFs by day 7 and in HGFs by day 2. Cytotoxicity was minimal, with only 2% observed in MEFs on days 2 and 3.
population_specificity: Mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) and human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs).
effective_dosage: 810 nm diode laser, 1J/cm², 12.5 mW, 80 s/well (single dose).
study_duration: Single irradiation after 1 day of incubation, with follow-up assessments on days 2, 3, and 7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of separate and simultaneous application of Tecar therapy and low-level laser therapy on neurological symptoms in type 2 diabetic patients with peripheral sensory neuropathy.
results_summary: The Tecar + laser group showed significant improvements in tibial MNCV and ABI compared to laser alone or Tecar alone, with lasting effects after three months. All groups showed neurological improvements after 10 sessions, but combined therapy yielded more durable benefits.
population_specificity: 45 type 2 diabetic patients (30 females, 15 males; mean age 65.7±7.6 years) with peripheral sensory neuropathy of the lower limbs.
study_duration: 10 sessions, with follow-up at three months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and intralesional injections in treating oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF) in grade II patients.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT reduced burning sensation and improved mouth opening in OSMF patients, but intralesional injections were significantly more effective in both outcomes.
population_specificity: 52 grade II OSMF patients aged 20-60 years.
effective_dosage: 0.1 watt laser, once for 3 cycles (1 minute each with 5-minute intervals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on soft tissue healing around dental implants and its potential mechanisms, including pain relief and inflammatory marker modulation.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced postoperative pain, improved clinical indicators (PICF volume, mSBI, GI), lowered TNF-α levels, and increased VEGF expression compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 58 patients (70 implants) who underwent dental implant surgery.
effective_dosage: LLLT with Nd:YAG (1064 nm) immediately after surgery and on the 2nd and 3rd day post-surgery.
study_duration: 3 days (intervention period), with outcomes measured up to 14 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on reducing lymphedema, improving limb function, and enhancing quality of life in post-mastectomy breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced arm volume in post-mastectomy lymphedema patients compared to conventional therapy, with a mean difference of 91.98 (95% CI = 41.99-141.97). However, no significant differences were observed in arm circumference reduction or pain scale improvement.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients with post-mastectomy lymphedema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in treating Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA), focusing on pain relief, grip strength, and morning stiffness.
results_summary: LLLT did not significantly reduce pain compared to placebo but significantly improved grip strength and reduced morning stiffness in RA patients, despite substantial heterogeneity in these outcomes.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy at two different wavelengths (660nm and 808nm) on pain, edema, and trismus in patients undergoing impacted lower third molar extraction.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between the groups, but both laser-treated groups reported reduced postoperative pain compared to the control group, suggesting LLLT may be beneficial as an adjunct therapy.
population_specificity: 30 patients undergoing impacted lower third molar extraction, divided into three groups (Control, 660nm, and 808nm).
effective_dosage: Irradiation before and immediately after the surgical procedure (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the outcomes of photobiomodulation therapy (LLLT) in wound healing, focusing on its effects on tissue regeneration and pain and inflammation reduction.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant benefits in wound epithelialization, pain reduction, and inflammation control by enhancing neurotransmitter activity and promoting osteoblast and fibroblast growth. All included studies reported a substantial contrast between control and laser-treated groups.
population_specificity: Humans (post-surgical hard and soft tissue healing) and animals (bone tissue healing).
effective_dosage: Various wavelengths and parameters (specifics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Er:YAG laser irradiation on human dental pulp stem cells (hDPSCs), particularly focusing on cell proliferation, hard tissue differentiation, and mineralization.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT combined with activators (VLT) significantly enhanced ALP activity, SMAD3 phosphorylation, mineralization, and hard tissue formation marker gene expression in hDPSCs, though TGF-β signaling inhibitors suppressed some effects.
population_specificity: Human dental pulp stem cells (hDPSCs) in an in vitro setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness and optimization of low-level laser therapy methods in treating multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy is a promising treatment for MS, demonstrating therapeutic mechanisms and positive results from several clinical studies. Optimal parameters such as wavelength, power, and exposure were emphasized for effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (mentions optimal values for wavelength, operation mode, power, frequency, exposure, etc.).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically examine the evidence for Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) effectiveness in sports and exercise medicine, focusing on immediate care settings and acute/subacute applications.
results_summary: LLLT shows promise in accelerating wound healing for body surface structures and improving exertion recovery, muscle strength, endurance, and reducing fatigue in sport performance studies. However, evidence is less convincing for acute, deep tissue injuries, where LLLT does not significantly outperform conventional therapies.
population_specificity: Athletes, trainers, and individuals with sports-related injuries or performance concerns.
effective_dosage: Not specified (wide ranges in parameters noted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore current trends and evidence regarding the use of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for the treatment and prevention of osteoradionecrosis.
results_summary: The review found that LLLT was used therapeutically (58%) and preventively (21%), with some studies employing antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (41%). Most in vivo studies used diode lasers in the near-infrared wavelength (67%), but variability in laser parameters and lack of comprehensive data hindered standardization.
population_specificity: Patients with or at risk of osteoradionecrosis.
effective_dosage: Diode lasers emitting low incident power densities at 660-904 nm (red and near-infrared wavelengths).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on wound healing and pain in skin wounds compared to untreated wounds through a meta-analysis.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved wound size reduction and complete healing rates compared to controls, and significantly reduced pain scores (VAS) post-treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with skin wounds (670 wounds analyzed across 18 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether postoperative 660-nm Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) reduces radiographic crestal bone loss in fresh-socket dental implants.
results_summary: The study found significantly lower bone resorption in the laser group compared to the no-laser group, suggesting LLLT effectively reduces bone resorption in fresh-socket implant placement.
population_specificity: Thirty patients referred for tooth extraction and fresh-socket implant placement.
effective_dosage: 660-nm LLLT administered three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the analgesic and preventive effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on incisional pain and neuropathic pain in rats, as well as identify potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant analgesic and preventive effects in the incisional pain model, reduced mechanical allodynia in the spinal nerve ligation (SNL) model, and decreased levels of IL-1β and NGF in peripheral tissues and the spinal cord dorsal horn.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats
effective_dosage: Single application before/after incision or SNL; consecutive application for 3-6 days (pre/post-incision or pre-SNL)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could reduce orthodontic relapse rates and improve periodontal tissue remodeling in rats.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced relapse rates compared to the control group, improved periodontal fiber arrangement, and increased BMP-2 expression, with no additional benefit from combining it with fulvic acids.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats undergoing orthodontic retention.
study_duration: 3 weeks of retention phase with assessments at days 7, 14, and 21.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of varying LLLT session frequencies on pain, maximum mouth opening, and quality of life in patients with masseter muscle trigger points.
results_summary: Increased LLLT sessions significantly reduced pain, improved maximum mouth opening, and enhanced quality of life, with statistically significant differences observed among the groups over the 8-week study period.
population_specificity: 90 patients with orofacial pain and masseter muscle trigger points for at least 6 months.
effective_dosage: Group I: 1 session/week; Group II: 2 sessions/week; Group III: 3 sessions/week.
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with follow-up evaluations up to 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing symptoms and improving clinical and electrophysiological outcomes in patients with Ulnar Neuropathy at the Elbow (UNE).
results_summary: The LLLT group showed significant improvements in pain, clinical findings, motor nerve conduction velocity (NCV), and motor distal latency (MDL) at post-treatment evaluations, as well as sensory NCV on the 15th day. Compared to the sham group, LLLT demonstrated greater improvements in pain scores, QuickDASH scores at three months, and sensory NCV on the 15th day, though no significant differences were found in weakness scores, grip strength, or other electrophysiological findings.
population_specificity: 68 patients aged 18-60 years diagnosed with UNE.
study_duration: Evaluations were performed before treatment, on the 15th day, and at the third month post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on clinical and sonographic parameters in patients with symptomatic rotator cuff calcific tendinitis (RCCT).
results_summary: Both groups improved in pain, range of motion, and functional status, but the LLLT group showed significantly better outcomes in reducing calcification number and severity, pain intensity, and disability compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 68 patients (76 shoulders) aged 18-75 with RCCT confirmed by ultrasound and over 3 months of shoulder pain.
effective_dosage: 5 LLLT sessions per week for 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and microsurgery for neurosensory recovery in patients with iatrogenic injuries to the inferior alveolar nerve (IAN) and lingual nerve (LN) sustained more than six months prior.
results_summary: LLLT demonstrated positive outcomes in both subjective and objective assessments of neurosensory function, even when applied beyond six months post-injury. Microsurgery also showed improvement but was recommended for early intervention, while LLLT exhibited promise as a minimally invasive option for delayed rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Patients with iatrogenic injuries to the IAN and LN sustained more than six months prior, predominantly female, with mean ages of 41.5 years (microsurgery) and 31.5 years (LLLT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of HILT+ET and LLLT+ET in reducing pain and improving function in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both HILT+ET and LLLT+ET significantly improved pain and function scores at weeks 4 and 8, with HILT+ET showing greater improvements than LLLT+ET by week 8.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on collagen type I synthesis, cell proliferation, and viability in human ligament fibroblasts derived from the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL).
results_summary: Fibroblasts showed decreased viability after low and high doses of LLLT, increased proliferation at the low dose, and increased collagen synthesis at the high dose on day 10 for both sexes after treatment. The study concluded that LLLT may improve early ligament healing by enhancing proliferation at low doses and collagen synthesis at high doses.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing arthroscopic ACL reconstruction surgery.
effective_dosage: Low dose (1.0 J/cm²), High dose (5.0 J/cm²), Control (0.0 J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating oral ulcerated lesions in a SARS-CoV-2 patient.
results_summary: Significant clinical improvement of oral lesions was observed after seven sessions of LLLT, allowing the patient to resume an oral diet. The study suggests LLLT may be effective for managing COVID-19-related oral lesions.
population_specificity: A single SARS-CoV-2 patient with oral ulcerated lesions, admitted to the intensive care unit on mechanical ventilation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain and improving sexual satisfaction in patients with orchialgia after varicocelectomy surgery.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT with red (650 nm, 50 mW) and infrared (820 nm, 100 mW) spectra significantly reduced pain and increased sexual satisfaction in patients 6 and 12 weeks after treatment.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with orchialgia after varicocelectomy surgery.
effective_dosage: 6-25 J/cm²/day, 15 minutes per session, three times a week for 12 sessions.
study_duration: 12 sessions over 4 weeks (3 sessions per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) affects the displacement of orthodontic miniscrews in sagittal, transverse, and vertical planes during canine retraction.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT did not significantly affect miniscrew displacement in any of the three planes compared to the control side. Both the laser-treated and control sides showed significant three-dimensional displacement after four months of canine retraction.
population_specificity: 12 adult patients who underwent upper first premolar extraction and canine retraction with orthodontic miniscrews.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy in managing pain and improving mouth opening in patients with temporomandibular joint arthralgia.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in pain (reduced VAS scores) and increased mouth opening after low-level laser therapy, with no observed remissions.
population_specificity: 50 patients with temporomandibular joint arthralgia.
effective_dosage: 8–15 J/cm², 3–5 sessions over a month, each lasting 15–20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on C. albicans colonies isolated from head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: LLLT at 5 and 10 J/cm² reduced C. albicans colonies by 7.01% and 10.94%, respectively, but the reductions were not statistically significant. Nystatin eliminated all colonies.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy at a dose exceeding 30 Gy.
effective_dosage: 5 J/cm² (0.1 W) and 10 J/cm² (0.2 W) for 50 seconds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-intensity laser therapy (LILT) in treating venous lesions based on existing literature.
results_summary: The study found that LILT improved healing and alleviated pain in patients with vasculogenic lesions, with wavelengths ranging from 635 nm to 780 nm. It was described as a low-cost and easy-to-apply adjuvant therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with venous or vasculogenic lesions.
effective_dosage: Wavelengths varied from 635 nm (red ray) to 780 nm (infrared ray); specific dosage and frequency not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) combined with Vitamin B supplementation could effectively improve facial muscle function and symmetry in patients with Peripheral Facial Palsy (PFP).
results_summary: Both patients showed significant improvement in facial muscle function and symmetry after six to seven LLLT sessions, with notable recovery in muscle tonicity, facial movements, and reduced paresthesia. The study suggests LLLT combined with Vitamin B supplementation may be a viable non-invasive treatment for PFP.
population_specificity: Two patients with PFP—a 52-year-old female with viral infection-induced PFP and a 33-year-old male with trauma-induced PFP.
effective_dosage: 4 Joules per point (10 points along the facial nerve pathway) every two weeks; 1 NEUROBIONTA tablet (Vitamin B1 + B6 + B12) daily for 30 days.
study_duration: Six to seven LLLT sessions (approximately 12-14 weeks) plus 30 days of Vitamin B supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combined wavelength (660 nm and 808 nm) Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could reduce postoperative pain in partially and fully edentulous patients after dental implant surgery.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant pain reduction at 24 and 72 hours for fully edentulous patients, with non-significant differences in pain episode duration. Pain levels decreased over time for both groups, but only the experimental group showed statistically significant improvements in specific intervals.
population_specificity: Partially and fully edentulous patients undergoing dental implant surgery.
effective_dosage: 22.5 Joules (J) per implant, administered immediately after surgery at 5 points per implant.
study_duration: Single dose administered post-surgery, with follow-up assessments at 24 h, 72 h, and 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pregnancy outcomes in individuals with recurrent implantation failure (RIF) who had undergone at least three unsuccessful embryo transfer cycles.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT pretreatment resulted in higher rates of biochemical and clinical pregnancies compared to the control group (46.7% vs. 33.3% and 33.3% vs. 20.0%, respectively), though the differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Thirty females with a history of RIF eligible for frozen-thawed embryo transfer (FET), mean age 34.17 years, who had undergone 3-7 previous embryo transfers.
effective_dosage: 900-milliwatt power output, 850-nm wavelength, transabdominal irradiation on the hypogastric area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF2) on the adhesion and proliferation of periodontal ligament stem cells (PDLSCs).
results_summary: LLLT did not notably decrease PDLSC viability or adhesion, while FGF2 had adverse effects when applied on the seeding day. After five days, LLLT-2 showed significantly higher proliferation compared to other groups.
population_specificity: Periodontal ligament stem cells (PDLSCs) in vitro.
effective_dosage: 808 nm diode laser in one (LLLT-1) or two sessions (LLLT-2) of irradiation.
study_duration: Evaluated on days 1, 3, and 5 post-cell seeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically analyze and summarize the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain scores and healing time in patients with recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT reduced pain scores in 13 out of 14 trials and shortened healing time in 4 trials, with a meta-analysis of two CO2 laser studies showing significantly faster healing compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS), excluding those with systemic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining low-level laser therapy (LLLT) with eccentric exercises provided additional benefits over eccentric exercises alone in treating midportion Achilles tendinopathy.
results_summary: The study found that while both groups (LLLT + eccentric exercises and placebo LLLT + eccentric exercises) showed significant improvement in VISA-A and VAS scores, there was no statistically significant difference between the groups at any time point, indicating LLLT did not enhance outcomes beyond eccentric exercises alone.
population_specificity: 60 clinically diagnosed patients with midportion Achilles tendinopathy, aged 18 to 60.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) in reducing sciatica pain in patients with chronic lumbar radiculopathy.
results_summary: LLLT was more effective than TENS in reducing leg and neuropathic pain, with lasting improvements in leg pain observed at the 3-month follow-up. Both treatments were effective, but LLLT showed superior results in specific pain measures.
population_specificity: 164 patients with chronic radicular pain caused by lumbar disk herniation (LDH), divided into three groups (LLLT, TENS, sham LLLT).
effective_dosage: 4 J/cm² per point, applied five days a week for three weeks (15 sessions).
study_duration: 3 weeks of treatment, with follow-up at 3 months.
